title: Eco-tourism can contribute over 20 million Birr per annum to Ethiopia’s revenueTravelandtourworld.com
text:
Eco-tourism can contribute over 20 million Birr per annum to Ethiopia’s revenue
Ethiopia has the potential to earn more than 20 billion Birr (about about 962 million US dollars) annually from eco-tourism, says a researcher with the Ethiopian Wild Life Conservation Authority, Mihret Ewnetu.
In countries such as Morocco and South Africa which earn huge revenues from tourism, 10 per cent of these earnings were derived from eco-tourism, he told the Ethiopian News Agency (ENA) here Thursday. Neighboring Kenya and Uganda also secure up to one billion USD annually from eco-tourism, he added.
Mihret said Ethiopia, which is endowed with diverse tourist attractions, earned only 60 million Birr annually from eco-tourism although the country was home to at least 16 types of endemic bird species which showed that the revenue earned from eco-tourism was too low.
According to him, the lack of sufficient promotional work in the sector was the reason for the poor performance of the eco-tourism sub-sector. There was insufficient activity in promoting the expanded new and old tourist attractions which limited the earnings, he pointed out.
The number of tourists visiting Ethiopia has jumped more than one million annually and activities are underway to achieve the plan to increase the figure to more than six million within the next five years.
